questions.text: At what BMI value is considered 'fatal' for men? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) <13 

 

  • A body mass index (BMI) of less than 13 in men is considered critically low and potentially fatal. 
  • This threshold indicates extreme undernutrition and can lead to severe health complications, potentially resulting in life-threatening conditions due to vital organ function impairment and failure. 
  • BMI is a measure of body fat based on height and weight that applies to adult men and women, and values significantly below normal can indicate serious health risks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An individual with a body mass index (BMI) of 13 or lower is deemed fatal for males. Nonetheless, females can endure with a BMI as low as 11 or even lower.

choices.text: Seen in 10% of individuals with symptomatic GERD
Increases risk of squamous cell carcinoma

questions.text: All are true about Barrett esophagus except: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increases risk of squamous cell carcinoma

 

Not squamous cell carcinoma, but esophageal adenocarcinoma is the cancer risk that is increased by Barrett's esophagus.

 

Barrett's esophagus is a premalignant condition.

 

Barrett's epithelium (columnar metaplasia), dysplasia, carcinoma in situ, and esophageal adenocarcinoma develop sequentially from one another.

 

Microscopically, goblet cells are shown to have taken the place of the squamous esophageal epithelium (intestinal metaplasia).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Complication of chronic GERD: True, as Barrett’s esophagus commonly develops as a response to the damage from chronic acid reflux.

 

Option B. Seen in 10% of individuals with symptomatic GERD: True, as approximately 10% of GERD patients develop Barrett's esophagus.

 

Option D. Intestinal metaplasia: True, and is a defining characteristic of Barrett’s esophagus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Barrett’s esophagus increases the risk of esophageal adenocarcinoma due to the transformation of squamous cells to columnar cells, not squamous cell carcinoma.

choices.text: Get consent from mother for P/V

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl presents to you with her mother, reporting abdominal discomfort and is found to be 12 weeks pregnant based on a positive urine pregnancy test. As a medical professional, what would be your initial course of action? [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Inform Police

 

Explanation

 

In many jurisdictions, pregnancy in a minor may be considered evidence of statutory rape or sexual abuse, hence, informing the police is crucial for legal proceedings and safeguarding the minor.

 

Other Option

 

Option A. Start examining: Although a medical examination is necessary, it must be conducted with proper legal and parental consent, especially considering the age and the situation's sensitivity.

 

Option C. Preserve clothing: This could be necessary in a case where forensic evidence needs to be gathered, especially if there was recent assault. However, this would follow legal reporting.

 

Option D. Take consent from mother: Consent is crucial, especially for minors. However, it does not preclude the obligation to report statutory rape or sexual abuse to authorities.

 

Educational objective :

 

  • When dealing with potentially criminal situations involving minors, such as a young teenager's pregnancy, the first step is to ensure the situation is addressed legally and safely. 
  • Informing law enforcement and ensuring proper medical and legal procedures safeguard the minor's health and legal rights.

questions.text: Which of the following viruses exhibits genetic re-assortment similar to that of influenza virus? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A

 

Rotavirus exhibit genetic reassortment similar to that of influenza virus.

 

Rotaviruses - Cartwheel-shaped structures with short spokes radiating from them. Genome consists of double-stranded RNA with 11 segments. Segmented RNA helps in easy reassortment of the genome.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Adenovirus can be identified by their icosahedral symmetry with and fibers extruding from the vertices. It is a double stranded DNA virus.

 

 

Option C. Ebola viruses are cylindrical/tubular, and contain viral envelope, matrix, and nucleocapsid components. The virus generally appears in a long, filamentous form, but it can also be “U-shaped,” in the shape of a “6” (the “shepherd’s crook” appearance), or even circular. It is non-segmented and contains single stranded RNA.

 

 

Option D. Rabies viruses belong to Rhabdoviridae which are bullet-shaped viruses with unsegmented single-stranded RNA

 

 

Educational Objective

 

Rotaviruses have a segmented RNA genome that allows them to undergo genetic reassortment similar to influenza viruses.

choices.text: Pituitary gland

questions.text: IGF-I is synthesized by which of the following organ? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Liver

 

Explanation

 

The predominant organ producing insulin-like growth factor I (IGF-I) is the liver. IGF-I is produced in response to stimulation by growth hormone (GH), which is primarily secreted by the pituitary gland. However, while GH stimulates IGF-I production, it is the liver that is responsible for producing the majority of circulating IGF-I in the body.

 

Growth hormone acts on the liver to form small proteins called "somatomedins"

 

  • Somatomedins increases bone growth in all aspect
  • Also called as insulin-like growth factor (IGF) as effects are similar to insulin
  • Four types are present - Most important is somatomedin C, specifically referred to as "insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1)
  • Binds to carrier protein in blood
  • Half-life - about 20 Hrs
  • Blood concentration of IGF-1, follows the levels of growth hormone.
  • Growth effects of GH are mostly attributed to somatomedin (rather than its direct effect on bones & peripheral tissues)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pituitary gland: Incorrect because while the pituitary gland secretes growth hormone that stimulates IGF-I production, it does not synthesize IGF-I itself.

 

Option C. Pancreas: Incorrect because the pancreas is involved in the production of insulin and other digestive enzymes, not IGF-I.

 

Option D. Adrenal glands: Incorrect because the adrenal glands produce corticosteroids and catecholamines, not IGF-I.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The liver is the primary organ responsible for the synthesis of insulin-like growth factor I (IGF-I), which is stimulated by growth hormone secreted from the pituitary gland.

 

Ref– Textbook of Medical physiology Guyton and Hall, 11th edition, page no. 924

questions.text: A patient came to the gynecology OPD with complaints of foul-smelling frothy vaginal discharge and intense itching. On examination, the cervix was spotted and had the appearance of a strawberry. Identify the causative organism? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Trichomonas vaginalis

 

  • Intense vaginal itching and foul-smelling greenish discharge are suggestive of Trichomonas vaginalis infection.
  • Strawberry like appearance of the cervix helps in establishing the diagnosis.
  • On vaginal smear, flagellated organism (T. vaginalis is seen)

 

Other Options:

 

Best understood by this table given below

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trichomonas vaginalis infection is characterized by foul-smelling, frothy yellowish-green discharge and a strawberry-like appearance of the cervix.

 

Ref: Page no 554, DC Dutta’s Textbook of gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: A biostatistics professor is teaching a group of medical students about the fundamentals of statistics. She mentions a branch that is specifically concerned with summarizing and presenting data in a meaningful way. Which of the following branches is she most likely referring to? [INICET MAY 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Descriptive statistics

 

Descriptive Statistics:

 

  • Data is summarised through the given observations; summarisation is done from a sample of population using parameters such as the mean or standard deviation.
  • Descriptive statistics is a way to organise, represent and describe a collection of data using tables, graphs, and summary measures

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Theoretical statistics: Focuses on the underlying mathematical theory and development of statistical methods, not on data summarization and presentation.

 

Option C. Analytical statistics: This term is less commonly used and does not represent a standard branch of statistics like descriptive or inferential statistics.

 

Option D. Inferential Statistics: Involves using data from a sample to make predictions or inferences about a larger population, including hypothesis testing and confidence intervals.

 

Additional Information

 

Applied Statistics:

 

  • Pure statistics focuses primarily on the numbers, maths, and problems themselves (theoretical)
  • Applied statistics on the other hand, can be thought of as “statistics-in-action” or using statistics with an eye toward real-world problems and what their solutions might be.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Descriptive statistics is dedicated to summarizing and presenting data in an easily understandable way, utilizing tables, graphs, and summary measures.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lienorenal ligament

 

The structure marked in the image is identified as the lienorenal ligament. The lienorenal ligament is a peritoneal ligament that connects the spleen to the left kidney. It is crucial because it contains important structures such as the splenic artery and vein.

 

In the provided image, you can see the vertebra centrally located, with the kidneys visible on each side. The spleen, which lies adjacent to the stomach, is connected to the kidney by the lienorenal ligament. The splenic artery, a branch of the celiac trunk, passes through this ligament.

 

During surgical procedures, especially when ligating the splenic artery, knowledge of this ligament's anatomy is essential.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gastrosplenic ligament: This ligament connects the greater curvature of the stomach to the spleen. It contains the short gastric arteries and the left gastroepiploic artery. However, in the provided image, the marked structure does not represent this ligament.

 

Option C. Lesser omentum: The lesser omentum is a double layer of peritoneum extending from the liver to the lesser curvature of the stomach and the first part of the duodenum. It contains the portal triad (portal vein, hepatic artery, and bile duct). The marked structure in the image is not the lesser omentum.

 

Option D. Greater omentum: This is a large apron-like fold of visceral peritoneum that hangs down from the greater curvature of the stomach. It covers the intestines but is not the structure marked in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lienorenal ligament is a peritoneal structure connecting the spleen to the kidney and contains the splenic artery. This ligament is essential for surgeons to identify, especially during procedures involving the spleen or splenic artery.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient arrives at the clinic with complaints of nasal obstruction on the right side and sporadic occurrences of blood-stained nasal discharge. The CT scan results are depicted in the image provided. What might be the potential underlying reason for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inverted Papilloma

 

An elderly patient with unilateral nasal obstruction, epistaxis and a mass visible points to a diagnosis of Inverted Papilloma.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Maxillary carcinoma arises from maxillary sinus lining and presents with facial paresthesia, lacrimation and pain.

 

 

Option C. Esthesioneuroblastoma/ Olfactory neuroblastomas are tumors arising from the basal layer of the olfactory epithelium in the superior recess of the nasal cavity. They usually present as a soft tissue mass in the superior olfactory recess involving the anterior and middle ethmoid air-cells on one side and extending through the cribriform plate into the anterior cranial fossa.

 

 

Option D. Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma is seen exclusively in males. Commonly presents with profuse epistaxis and nasal obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inverted Papilloma should be considered when an elderly patient presents with unilateral nasal symptoms and imaging reveals a mass, especially when the presentation includes epistaxis and nasal obstruction without the severe pain or neurological symptoms that might suggest a more malignant etiology.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of depression was initially being treated with sertraline, but his symptoms were not adequately controlled. His medication regimen was changed to include an MAO inhibitor and amitriptyline. Shortly after the change in medication, the patient developed agitation, seizures, hyperreflexia, and tremors. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cyproheptadine

  

The patient’s symptoms of agitation, seizures, hyperreflexia, and tremors are indicative of serotonin syndrome. Serotonin syndrome is a potentially life-threatening condition that occurs due to excessive serotonergic activity in the nervous system, usually as a result of combining medications that increase serotonin levels, such as SSRIs, MAO inhibitors, and TCAs. In this case, the combination of sertraline (an SSRI), an MAO inhibitor, and amitriptyline (a TCA) significantly increases serotonin, leading to the development of serotonin syndrome.

 

Symptoms of Serotonin Syndrome: (Mnemonic – RASH D)

 

  • Restlessness
  • Agitation
  • Seizures
  • Hyperreflexia
  • Diarrhea

 

Cyproheptadine is an antihistamine with serotonin receptor antagonist properties, making it the drug of choice for treating serotonin syndrome. It works by blocking serotonin receptors, thereby reducing the excessive serotonergic activity causing the symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. Lorazepam: Lorazepam is a benzodiazepine used to manage agitation and seizures but does not directly treat the underlying cause of serotonin syndrome. It is used as supportive therapy but is not the primary treatment.

 

Option C. L-carnitine: L-carnitine is a supplement often used in metabolic conditions and does not play a role in treating serotonin syndrome. It has no effect on serotonin levels or receptor activity.

 

Option D. Leucovorin: Leucovorin is a form of folic acid used as a rescue agent in methotrexate toxicity and other specific conditions. It has no role in the management of serotonin syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serotonin syndrome can occur when serotonergic drugs are combined, such as SSRIs, MAO inhibitors, and TCAs. The treatment of choice for serotonin syndrome is Cyproheptadine, a serotonin receptor antagonist.

questions.text: Which is the most suitable agent for IV regional anesthesia? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lidocaine

 

Lidocaine is the most suitable agent for intravenous (IV) regional anesthesia, commonly known as Bier's block. This technique is typically used for short surgical procedures (less than one hour) on the extremities.

 

Why Lidocaine is Preferred:

 

  • Rapid Onset: Lidocaine acts quickly, which is beneficial for short procedures.
  • Duration: It provides adequate duration of anesthesia for procedures typically performed under IV regional anesthesia.
  • Safety: Lidocaine is less cardiotoxic compared to Bupivacaine, making it safer for this type of anesthesia where high doses are confined to a limb.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bupivacaine: Bupivacaine is contraindicated for IV regional anesthesia due to its cardiotoxicity, which can be life-threatening if the tourniquet fails and the drug enters the systemic circulation.

 

Option C. Mepivacaine: Mepivacaine is less commonly used for IV regional anesthesia compared to Lidocaine, although it can be used in some settings.

 

Option D. Procaine: Procaine is not typically used for IV regional anesthesia due to its slower onset and shorter duration compared to Lidocaine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lidocaine is the preferred agent for IV regional anesthesia due to its rapid onset, suitable duration, and safety profile. This technique, known as Bier's block, is commonly used for short procedures on the extremities, requiring careful management to avoid systemic toxicity.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with thyroid swelling. Blood tests show elevated TSH levels and the presence of thyroid peroxidase antibodies. Histopathological examination revealed the presence of Hurthle cells. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hashimoto thyroiditis

 

This clinical scenario with the presence of Hurthle cells is suggestive of Hashimoto's thyroiditis.

 

It is an autoimmune disease that causes the thyroid gland to gradually deteriorate, eventually leading to thyroid failure. It is most common in women between the ages of 45 and 65. The presence of circulating autoantibodies against thyroglobulin and thyroid peroxidase causes it.

 

There is a diffuse enlargement of the thyroid gland with an intact capsule morphologically. It is clearly separated from the surrounding structures.

 

There are two types of Hashimoto's thyroiditis: the classic form, which is more common, and the fibrosing variant, which occurs in only 10% of cases.

 

The classic form is distinguished by diffuse, symmetric, firm, and rubbery thyroid enlargement. The fibrosing variant has a firm, enlarged thyroid with surrounding tissue compression.

 

Histologically:

 

  1. Classic form has intense lymphocytic infiltration, atrophied thyroid follicles, and follicular epithelial cells that have degenerated into Hurthle cells (also called Askanazy cells, or oxyphil cells, or oncocytes).
  2. The fibrosing variant of Hashimoto's thyroiditis is characterized by significant fibrous replacement of thyroid parenchyma and a less prominent lymphoid infiltrate

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Graves' disease: Characterized by hyperthyroidism, presence of anti-TSH receptor antibodies, and typically does not present with Hurthle cells.

 

  • Clinical features include exophthalmos, pretibial myxedema, and a diffusely enlarged hypervascular thyroid gland.

 

Option C. Follicular carcinoma: A type of thyroid cancer that presents with different histological features, such as follicular cell proliferation and capsular or vascular invasion, but not typically Hurthle cells.

 

Option D. Medullary carcinoma of thyroid: Arises from parafollicular C cells and is associated with amyloid deposits and elevated calcitonin levels.

 

  • Histologically different from Hashimoto's thyroiditis and does not feature Hurthle cells.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: The micronutrient deficient in a patient with anemia, neutropenia, and hypopigmentation of skin and hair is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cu (Copper)

 

Copper deficiency can present with anemia, neutropenia, and hypopigmentation of the skin and hair. Copper is a crucial cofactor for several enzymes, including tyrosinase, which is involved in the conversion of tyrosine to melanin, the pigment responsible for skin and hair color. When copper is deficient, melanin production decreases, leading to hypopigmentation. Additionally, copper plays a role in iron metabolism and immune function, which explains the anemia and neutropenia observed in copper deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Zn (Zinc): Zinc deficiency is characterized by delayed wound healing, immune dysfunction, hypogonadism, and diarrhea. While zinc is important for various enzymatic functions, it does not specifically cause hypopigmentation or the combination of anemia and neutropenia seen with copper deficiency.

 

Option B. Se (Selenium): Selenium deficiency is associated with Keshan disease, which primarily affects the heart and can lead to cardiomyopathy. Selenium plays a role in antioxidant protection but does not cause the symptoms described in the question.

 

Option C. Fe (Iron): Iron deficiency primarily causes microcytic anemia, fatigue, and pallor. It does not lead to neutropenia or hypopigmentation of the skin and hair.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Copper deficiency is associated with anemia, neutropenia, and hypopigmentation due to its role in melanin synthesis and various other enzymatic processes.

questions.text: Book test is for: (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ulnar nerve

 

TESTS FOR ULNAR NERVE PALSY

 

  • Froment sign/book test: Hyperflexion of the thumb IP joint while attempting to pinch. This indicates a substitution of flexor pollicis longus (innervated by median nerve) for adductor pollicis (innervated by ulnar nerve).

 

 

  • Jeanne sign: Reciprocal hyperextension of the thumb MCP joint indicating substitution of flexor pollicis longus (FPL) for adductor pollicis.

 

 

  • Wartenburg sign: Abduction of the small finger at MCP joint indicating deficient palmar intrinsic muscle (innervated by ulnar nerve) with abduction from extensor digiti minimi (innervated by the radial nerve).

 

 

  • Duchenne sign: Clawing of the ring and small fingers, hyperextension of MCP joints, and flexion of PIP joints indicating deficient interosseous and lumbrical muscles of the ring and small fingers.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Median nerve. Special tests for median nerve injury are:

 

  • Pen Test:
    • Test: Patient keeps his/her hand flat on the table and at the same time, examiner brings a pen above the thumb.
    • Interpretation: Patient tries to touch the pen by abduction the thumb and examiner feels the tendon of abductor pollicis brevis (APB) at the wrist. Patient fails to touch in APB paralysis and examiner will not be able to palpate the tendon.
    • Note: Median nerve invariably and exclusively supply APB.

 

 

  • Pointing Index Sign/Ochsner’s Clasping/Benediction Test:
    • Test: Patient clasps his both hand together.
    • Interpretation: The index finger fails to flex in median nerve injury and it points outward as pointing index.
    • Note: It occur in high median nerve palsy where flexor digitorum superficialis and lateral half of flexor digitorum profundus gets involved.

 

 

A. Pointing index; B. Benediction test

 

Option C. Posterior interosseous nerve. The patient may exhibit weakness with finger extension. When asked to make a fist, the wrist may deviate radially due to extensor carpi ulnaris weakness. Depending on injury severity there may be a positive Tinel sign at the site of injury.

 

Option D. Radial nerve. Special tests for radial nerve palsy are:

 

  • Wrist drop test:
    • The patient is asked to extend wrist with the elbow flexed 90°.
    • In radial nerve palsy affecting the wrist extensors, the patient will be unable to extend the wrist. The hand will hang down in a deformity known as a “wrist drop“.

 

 

a. Normal; b. Wrist drop

 

  • In a second stage of the test, the patient is asked to abduct the thumb.
  • In radial nerve palsy, the patient will be unable to abduct the thumb because of the paralysis of the abductor pollicis longus muscle and, to a lesser extent, the extensor pollicis brevis muscle.

 

 

a. Thumb abduction; b. Paralysis

 

  • Thumb extension test:
    • The examiner grasps the patient’s wrist with one hand and presses the thumb into adduction with the other hand.
    • Then the patient is asked to extend or abduct both the metacarpophalangeal and interphalangeal joints of the thumb.
    • Where this nerve is damaged, thumb extension will be weakened or impossible as a result of paralysis of the extensor pollicis longus and brevis.

 

 

a. Starting position; b. Normal; c. Weak thumb extension

 

  • Supination test:
    • Supination Test evaluates compression neuropathy of the deep branch of the radial nerve.
    • The patient is seated, holding the elbow slightly flexed and the forearm pronated.
    • The elbow is held alongside the trunk to minimize motion in the shoulder.
    • The patient is then asked to supinate forearm, at first normally and then against the examiner’s resistance.
    • Weakness or loss of supination of the forearm is a sign of paresis of the supinator muscle, which is supplied by the deep branch of the radial nerve.

 

 

a. Starting position; b. Normal supination; c. Supination against resistance

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Book test is done for ulnar nerve palsy where there is hyperflexion of the thumb IP joint while attempting to pinch, indicating a substitution of flexor pollicis longus (innervated by median nerve) for adductor pollicis (innervated by ulnar nerve).

choices.text: A-1, B-3, C-4, D-2
A-2, B-1, C-4, D-3
A-3, B-4, C-1, D-2
A-4, B-1, C-2, D-3

questions.text: Match the following bacteria with the drug of choice used for each? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. A-2, B-1, C-4, D-3

 

  1. Vancomycin is Drug of Choice for Methicillin-Resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) – It acts by inhibiting the cell wall synthesis and is a bactericidal drug.
  2. Metronidazole drug of choice against anaerobic infections caused by Bacteroides.
  3. Meropenem is used in infections caused by Klebsiella. Klebsiella is known to produce ESBL (Extended Spectrum Beta Lactamases). Carbapenems are not hydrolyzed by ESBL. Therefore, carbapenems like imipenem, meropenem, ertapenem are indicated in the treatment of infections caused by ESBL producing bacteria.
  4. Penicillin like amoxicillin, ampicillin can be used in H. influenzae infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Metronidazole is the drug of choice for anaerobic infections caused by Bacteroides.
  • Vancomycin is the drug of choice for infections caused by MRSA.
  • Penicillins like amoxicillin and ampicillin are used for Haemophilus influenzae infections.
  • Meropenem is used for infections caused by Klebsiella, particularly ESBL-producing strains.

choices.text: Statement 1 is false and Statement 2 is true
Statement 1 is true and Statement 2 is false
Both the statements are true but 2 is not the conclusion of 1
Both the statements are true and 2 is the conclusion of 1

questions.text:
Statement 1: Clinically a patient having flaccid bullae with painful erosions, will show Suprabasal split and inflammatory infiltrate in the blister cleft on histopathological examination.

 

Statement 2: Row of tombstones appearance is diagnostic of Pemphigus vulgaris (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both the statements are true but 2 is not the conclusion of 1

 

Both statements are true about Pemphigus vulgaris but statement 2 is not explaining 1.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pemphigus vulgaris, a blistering autoimmune skin condition. The condition is characterized by suprabasal acantholysis (a separation of skin cells above the basal cell layer), leading to the formation of flaccid bullae with painful erosions. The "row of tombstones" appearance describes a specific histological feature of Pemphigus vulgaris.

questions.text: All of the following coagulation factors increase in pregnancy except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Factor XI

 

Pregnancy induces a hypercoagulable state to prepare the body for the increased risk of bleeding during delivery. This state is characterized by an increase in several coagulation factors, which enhances clot formation.

 

  • Factor II (Prothrombin): Increases during pregnancy. This contributes to a higher risk of clotting.
  • Factor VII: Increases during pregnancy, aiding in the clotting process.
  • Factor VIII: Also increases during pregnancy, enhancing clotting factors and overall coagulation.
  • Factor XI: Does not increase during pregnancy. In fact, Factor XI levels are slightly decreased in pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Factor II: Factor II increases during pregnancy, contributing to the hypercoagulable state.

 

Option B. Factor VII: Factor VII levels increase during pregnancy, supporting the increased coagulation needed.

 

Option C. Factor VIII: Factor VIII increases during pregnancy, which is consistent with the overall increase in clotting factors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Factor XI is the coagulation factor that does not increase during pregnancy and may actually decrease slightly.

 

Ref: Page no 508, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: Egg shell calcification is seen in all the following, except? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Metastatic lymph node

 

Explanation:

 

A ring of calcification at the periphery of a lymph node is known as eggshell calcification.

 

While calcifications can occur in metastatic nodes, they usually do not form the classic eggshell pattern. Instead, calcifications in metastatic nodes are often more irregular or diffusely distributed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Silicosis: This condition, often seen in individuals exposed to silica dust, can lead to eggshell calcification of the lymph nodes due to chronic inflammation and fibrosis.

 

Option B. Sarcoidosis: Another granulomatous disease that can lead to eggshell calcification in lymph nodes as part of its systemic manifestation affecting the lungs and lymphatic system.

 

Option C. Post-radiation therapy lymph nodes: Radiation can induce changes in lymph node structure including calcifications, commonly in a peripheral pattern, as a late sequela of treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eggshell calcification is a specific radiologic sign associated with certain granulomatous diseases and post-treatment changes but is not commonly seen in metastatic lymph nodes. It may be seen in:

 

  1. Silicosis
  2. Sarcoidosis
  3. post-radiation therapy in lymph nodes
  4. post-ATT in lymph nodes in TB

choices.text: Karyotype is 46 XY
Ovotestis is seen in the gonadal biopsy
The response of testosterone to hCG is increased
Uterus is usually absent

questions.text: What is true about ovotesticular disorders of sex development? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ovotestis is seen in the gonadal biopsy

 

  • Ovotesticular disorder of sex development (DSD) is characterized by the presence of both ovarian and testicular tissue in the same individual.
  • Most affected individuals have a 46, XX chromosomal karyotype, which normally results in female sexual development.
  • In about 10% of patients, testicular tissue in an individual with a 46, XX karyotype is present as a result of a translocation of the SRY gene on the Y chromosome to the X chromosome or another chromosome.
  • An abnormal vagina and underdeveloped uterus are usually present.
  • The testes are usually undescended, and the penis may present with hypospadias.
  • Upon reaching puberty, breast development, feminization, and menstruation may occur.
  • Most affected individuals are infertile, but ovulation or spermatogenesis is possible.
  • The response of testosterone to hCG is normal or reduced.
  • A defect in R-spondin1 protein encoded by the RSPO1 gene is described in 46, XX ovotesticular DSD.
  • An ovotestis is present in approximately 2/3 of affected individuals.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ovotesticular disorder of sex development is characterized by the presence of both ovarian and testicular tissues, typically with a 46, XX karyotype and possible SRY gene translocation, and can present with ovotestis seen on gonadal biopsy.

questions.text: Within the framework of Sustainable Development Goal 3, the objective of target 3.1 is to achieve a reduction in the Maternal Mortality Ratio to what specific level (per 1 lakh live birts) by the year 2030? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) <70

 

In Sustainable Development Goal 3, the target 3.1 aims to reduce the Maternal Mortality Ratio by 2030 to <70 per 1 lakh live births.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

SDGs – Targets & Indicators

 

3.1 - By 2030, MMR < 70

3.2 - By 2030, NNMR 12 & U5MR 25

3.3 - By 2030, end epidemics of AIDS, TB, Malaria and NTDs and combat Hepatitis, Water-borne diseases and other CDS.

3.4 - By 2030, reduce by 1/3 premature mortality from NCDs.

3.5 - Strengthen the prevention & treatment of substance abuse.

3.6 - By 2020, halve the global deaths and injuries form RTA.

3.7 - By 2030, universal access to Sexual & Rep – health care services.

3.8 - Achieve Universal health coverage.

3.9 - By 2030, reduce the number of deaths, illnesses form hazardous chemicals and air, water and soil pollution and contamination.

questions.text:
Among the listed causes of alopecia, which one(s) result in non-scarring alopecia? (INICET May 2022)

 

  1. Alopecia areata
  2. Telogen effluvium
  3. Androgenic alopecia
  4. Frontal fibrosing alopecia
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, and 3

 

 

Non cicatricial alopecia classification:

 

 

Option 1 - Alopecia areata:

 

  • It is a persistent autoimmune condition characterized by non-scarring hair loss patches.
  • This inflammatory disease involves T cells and primarily affects individuals with genetic susceptibility, being associated with HLA DR4, DR5, DQ3.
  • The condition is identifiable by "exclamation mark hairs" – short, fragile hairs that taper toward the base, as illustrated in the image below.

 

 

  • Alopecia totalis refers to the complete loss of scalp hair.
  • Alopecia universalis involves the loss of all body hair.
  • In instances of limited alopecia areata, approximately 80% of patients experience spontaneous remission.
  • Alopecia areata predominantly affects pigmented hair.
  • In older individuals, gray hair may consist of both white and colored hair. If the disease progresses rapidly, only the colored hair will be affected and lost, leaving the white hair unaffected in the patches of hair loss.
  • This sudden change in hair color is known as "Turning white overnight".

 

The following image depicts sparing of white hair within patches of hair loss.

 

 

Fig: Alopecia areata " Turning white overnight"

 

Option 2 - Telogen effluvium:

 

  • It is an acute onset of scalp hair loss that starts one to two months after a trigger, such as a high fever, infections (Cholera, Typhoid, Covid), trauma from surgery or other trauma, starvation, MI, Pregnancy, or hemorrhage.
  • It refers to an increase in the shedding of telogen club hairs due to premature termination of anagen proliferative phase of the hair cycle following a period of stress.
  • Telogen hair shedding that lasts longer than six months is known as chronic diffuse telogen hair loss.
  • Thyroid conditions (both hyper- and hypothyroidism), severe iron deficiency Anemia, acrodermatitis enteropathica, and malnutrition are the main causes of chronic diffuse telogen hair loss.

 

Option 3 - Androgenetic Alopecia

 

  • The disorder known as androgenetic alopecia is characterized by the miniaturization & reduction of hair follicle production.
  • Male pattern hair loss and female pattern hair loss are the two types.
  • Recession of the frontal hairline and vertex thinning are seen in male pattern hair loss.
  • Females may experience male pattern hair loss, and the opposite is also true.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option 4 - Frontal fibrosing alopecia

 

  • Frontal fibrosing alopecia is a scalp condition that affects post-menopausal women in particular and frequently involves the eyebrows.
  • It is a type of primary cicatricial (scarring) alopecia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Non-scarring alopecia’s do not destroy the hair follicle and allow for the possibility of hair regrowth.
  • Scarring alopecia’s involve destruction and replacement of the hair follicle with scar tissue, leading to permanent hair loss.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 89 page no 89.25, 28, 33

Fitzpatrick’s dermatology 9th edition page 1509

Online resource: https://www.bmj.com/content/347/bmj.f6112

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with a history of recurrent bacterial and fungal infections, particularly involving the skin and respiratory tract. The patient's parents report that he has had multiple abscesses and lymphadenitis. Dihydro-rhodamine test results show an abnormal pattern. What is the primary suspicion based on these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chronic Granulomatous Disease

 

Explanation

 

Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD) is a genetic disorder that affects the body's ability to produce reactive oxygen species (ROS) necessary to kill certain bacteria and fungi. This condition is most commonly inherited in an X-linked recessive manner due to a defect in the CYBB gene, which encodes a component of the NADPH oxidase enzyme complex.

 

Patients with CGD typically present with recurrent bacterial and fungal infections, particularly affecting the skin, lungs, and lymph nodes. The dihydro-rhodamine (DHR) test, which measures the oxidative burst of neutrophils, is used to diagnose CGD. An abnormal DHR test indicates a defect in the NADPH oxidase enzyme, confirming the diagnosis of CGD.

 

Investigation – NBT and DHR 123 test (flow cytometry)

 

TOC – Allogenic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation; IFN gamma

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Severe Combined Immunodeficiency (SCID): SCID is characterized by a severe defect in both T- and B-lymphocyte systems. It presents very early in life with severe immunodeficiency and is often due to adenosine deaminase deficiency.

 

Option C. Sialyl Lewis X defect: This results in leukocyte adhesion defect type 2 (LAD-2), which involves issues with leukocyte migration due to defective carbohydrate metabolism affecting leukocyte rolling.

 

Option D. Leukocyte Adhesion Defect (LAD): LAD type 1 involves a defect in the CD18 gene affecting leukocyte adhesion and migration, leading to recurrent infections without pus formation and poor wound healing. LAD type 2 involves a defect in the Sialyl Lewis X structure.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

Chronic Granulomatous Disease is diagnosed with the DHR test, which reveals defects in the oxidative burst of neutrophils due to NADPH oxidase deficiency.

choices.text: Release of reactive oxygen species and free radicles
Suppression of angiogenesis
Inhibition of IL2, IL4, IL5

questions.text: Which of these options is not a mechanism contributing to thalidomide's teratogenic effects? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Inhibition of IL2, IL4, IL5

 

The teratogenic effects of thalidomide arise from a combination of factors such as oxidative stress, inhibition of blood vessel formation (anti-angiogenesis), and its interaction with a specific protein known as cereblon. This protein, CRBN, plays a significant role in the formation of cerebral tissues. Notably, its presence in various brain regions, including the hippocampus, is linked to functions like memory and learning processes.

 

Other Options:

 

Thalidomide's teratogenic effects are caused by several mechanisms, which include:

 

Option A. Release of reactive oxygen species (ROS) and free radicals: Thalidomide induces oxidative stress, leading to cellular damage during development, which is one of the key factors in its teratogenicity. ROS and free radicals cause damage to cellular components, leading to malformations.

 

Option B. Suppression of angiogenesis: Thalidomide inhibits the formation of new blood vessels, a critical process during embryogenesis. This suppression leads to improper development of limbs and organs, contributing significantly to the teratogenic effects seen in affected fetuses.

 

Option C. Cereblon binding: Thalidomide’s interaction with cereblon (CRBN), a protein crucial for limb and organ development, is another major mechanism of its teratogenicity. The binding of thalidomide to CRBN disrupts its normal function, leading to developmental abnormalities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thalidomide’s teratogenicity is primarily due to oxidative stress, inhibition of angiogenesis, and binding to cereblon, rather than the inhibition of interleukins IL2, IL4, and IL5.

questions.text: Zika virus is transmitted by: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aedes aegypti

 

Zika virus may be transmitted by the bite of infected Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus.

 

The symptoms of Zika virus disease include fever, rash, conjunctivitis, muscle and joint pain, malaise, or headache. These symptoms are mild and usually last for 2-7 days.

 

Zika virus infection during pregnancy may cause lead to microcephaly or congenital Zika syndrome.

 

The complications of Zika virus infection include Guillain-Barré syndrome, neuropathy, and myelitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Culex: This genus of mosquitoes is not a known vector for Zika virus but is commonly associated with the transmission of the West Nile virus.

 

Option C. Anopheles: Known primarily for transmitting malaria, not Zika virus.

 

Option D. Phlebotomus papatasii: These are sandflies and known vectors for the virus causing leishmaniasis, not Zika.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aedes aegypti mosquitoes are the primary vectors for the transmission of Zika virus. Effective prevention and control measures involve protecting against mosquito bites through the use of insect repellents, bed nets, and eliminating standing water where mosquitoes breed. Awareness of the risks associated with Zika, particularly for pregnant women, is crucial for preventing infection and its severe consequences.

questions.text: Patient had difficulty in walking upstairs. When he was made to bear weight on right lower limb, the left-sided pelvis dropped down, but when he was standing on the left lower limb, the right-sided pelvis moved up. Which of the following is the likely lesion? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Right superior gluteal nerve palsy

 

WADDLING (GLUTEAL OR TRENDELENBURG) GAIT

 

  • This gait is characteristic of the gluteal muscle weakness that is seen in the progressive muscular dystrophies, but it occurs as well in chronic forms of spinal muscular atrophy, in certain inflammatory myopathies, lumbosacral nerve root compression, and with congenital dislocation of the hips.
  • It can also occur in neurogenic conditions in which the superior gluteal nerve is involved.
  • In normal walking, as weight is placed alternately on each leg, the hip is fixated by the gluteal muscles, particularly the gluteus medius, allowing for a slight rise of the opposite hip and tilt of the trunk to the weight-bearing side.
  • With weakness of the glutei, however, there is a failure to stabilize the weight-bearing hip, causing it to bulge outward and the opposite side of the pelvis to drop, with inclination of the trunk to that side.
  • The alternation in lateral trunk movements results in the roll or waddle.
  • With unilateral gluteal weakness, often the result of damage to the first sacral nerve root, tilting and dropping of the pelvis (“pelvic ptosis”) is apparent on only one side as the patient overlifts the leg when walking.
  • In several of the muscular dystrophies, an accentuation of lumbar lordosis is often seen.
  • Also, childhood cases may be complicated by muscular contractures, leading to an equinovarus position of the foot, so that the waddle is combined with walking on the toes (“toe walking”).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Left superior gluteal nerve palsy. When the patient is standing on one leg, the opposite pelvis should be lifted upwards by abduction of the ipsilateral hip joint, in a normal patient. When the abductors are weak due to superior gluteal nerve paresis, the pelvis will sag, called positive Trendelenburg sign. In a patient with a positive Trendelenburg sign, the pelvis sags toward the normal unsupported side, which is the swing leg. When the left superior gluteal nerve is affected, on standing on the left lower limb, the right side pelvis will drop and when the patient stands on the right leg, the left side pelvis will be lifted up.

 

Option C. Right inferior gluteal nerve palsy. The inferior gluteal nerve supplies the gluteus maximus muscle. It is therefore, responsible for extending the trunk from a forward bending position and extending the hip from sitting-to-standing or during stair-climbing or rising from a squatted position. The nerve does not confer any sensation. Injury to this nerve is most commonly iatrogenic in origin and is the most at risk nerve during total hip arthroplasty via a posterior approach. Injury typically leads to an altered gait pattern known as gluteus maximus ‘lurch’. The sequelae of nerve injury are denervation of the ipsilateral gluteus maximus muscle. The lurching gait results from the weakening or absence of an ipsilateral hip extension. Clinically, patients may also report wasting of the ipsilateral gluteus maximus muscle and loss of the defined shape to the affected buttock. In a normal gait cycle, the gluteus maximus begin to contract at the moment of the ipsilateral heel-strike to initiate ipsilateral hip extension. In inferior gluteal nerve injury, the trunk will extend when the heel strikes on the ground on the affected side to compensate for weak/absent hip extension. This backward trunk lurch is present in the whole stance phase of the gait cycle and locks the hip in extension. In some cases, the hamstrings muscle compensates to an extent. Therefore, in the right inferior gluteal nerve palsy, the right side hip will not extend during the initial heel strike and the trunk will lean backwards/extend.

 

Option D. Left inferior gluteal nerve palsy. In the injury of left sided gluteal nerve, the left hip will not extend during the initial heel strike, leading to backward lurch or extension of the trunk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • On standing on the right lower limb, the left side pelvis drops and while standing on the left leg, the right side pelvis lifted up. This is indicative of right superior gluteal nerve palsy. This sign is called Trendelenburg Sign.

questions.text: Asherman syndrome is most commonly associated with? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypomenorrhea

 

  • Asherman syndrome is the presence of uterine synechiae, due to the destruction of the endometrium. It can occur because of
    • Trauma to the endometrium following vigorous curettages such as incomplete abortion, postpartum hemorrhage, and elective abortion.
    • Genital tuberculosis
  • C/F: Following a D & C, they present with
    • Hypomenorrhea
    • Secondary amenorrhoea
    • Secondary infertility
  • The diagnosis is made by
    • HSG: Moth eaten appearance/ intra cavitary filling defects
    • Hysteroscopy: Intra uterine adhesions are seen

 

 

  • Management: Hysteroscopic adhesiolysis f/b insertion of an IUCD for 3 months and giving estrogen to build the endometrium

 

 Other Options:

 

Option A. Oligomenorrhea: This refers to infrequent menstruation, which is not the primary symptom of Asherman syndrome. Although it can occur, hypomenorrhea is more characteristic of the condition.

 

Option C. Dysmenorrhea: This means painful menstruation, which is not typically associated with Asherman syndrome.

 

Option D. Menorrhagia: This refers to heavy menstrual bleeding. Asherman syndrome usually leads to hypomenorrhea rather than menorrhagia due to the reduced endometrial surface area.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Asherman syndrome is most commonly associated with hypomenorrhea due to intrauterine adhesions following endometrial trauma.

 

Ref: Page no 459, DC Dutta’s Textbook of gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: A researcher in epidemiology is planning to conduct a meta-analysis to better understand the effects of a specific intervention. While he lists the various stages and processes associated with a meta-analysis, he includes one element that isn't typically involved in a meta-analysis. Which of the following isn't directly associated with the process of a meta-analysis? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Randomization 

 

  • Randomization is not a part of the meta-analysis process but is a critical component of randomized controlled trials (RCTs), which may be included in a meta-analysis.
  • Meta-analysis involves analysis of multiple studies together.
  • Steps of Meta-analysis involves Hypothesis formation, Study selection, Formulation of data, Analysis of data, examining bias, formulating conclusion.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Selection: Involves selecting studies for inclusion in the meta-analysis.

 

Option B. Analysis: Involves statistical analysis of the combined data from the selected studies.

 

Option D. Abstraction: Involves extracting data from the studies for inclusion in the meta-analysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Randomization is a part of conducting individual randomized controlled trials, not the process of performing a meta-analysis.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic presented with anorexia, nausea, vomiting and epigastric pain radiating towards the back. On investigation, Serum amylase is 1400; all other lab parameters are normal, what is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acute Pancreatitis

 

The patient's presentation and laboratory findings are suggestive of acute pancreatitis. Key symptoms and findings supporting this diagnosis include:

 

  • Epigastric pain radiating to the back: This is a classic symptom of acute pancreatitis. The pain is typically severe, constant, and often relieved by leaning forward.
  • Nausea and vomiting: These are common symptoms associated with acute pancreatitis.
  • Elevated serum amylase: A serum amylase level of 1400 U/L is significantly elevated, which is a hallmark of acute pancreatitis. Amylase levels typically rise within 6-12 hours of onset and can remain elevated for several days.

 

Signs and Symptoms of Acute Pancreatitis:

 

  • Pain: Acute onset of severe epigastric pain that radiates to the back.
  • Nausea and vomiting: Common accompanying symptoms.
  • Physical signs: May include hypotension, tachycardia, and tachypnea.
  • Characteristic discoloration:
    • Grey Turner's sign: Bluish discoloration of the flanks.
    • Cullen's sign: Bluish discoloration around the umbilicus.
    • Fox's sign: Discoloration below the inguinal ligament.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acute Cholecystitis:

 

  • Symptoms: Right upper quadrant pain, nausea, and food aversion. Pain does not typically radiate to the back as in pancreatitis.
  • Serum Amylase: Usually not significantly elevated in acute cholecystitis.

 

Option C. Acute Appendicitis:

 

  • Symptoms: Periumbilical pain that later shifts to the right lower quadrant (McBurney's point). Pain typically does not radiate to the back.
  • Serum Amylase: Not elevated in acute appendicitis.

 

Option D. Chronic Hepatitis:

 

  • Symptoms: May include fatigue, jaundice, anorexia, and abdominal discomfort, but not typically severe epigastric pain radiating to the back.
  • Serum Amylase: Not elevated in chronic hepatitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute pancreatitis should be suspected in a patient with severe epigastric pain radiating to the back, especially with significantly elevated serum amylase levels.

questions.text: A mother brought her 3-year-old child with cataract for second opinion. The child appears orthotropic and fine. What will be the management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cataract surgery

 

The likely management if the cataract is visually significant would be Cataract Surgery. Early intervention with cataract surgery is critical in children to prevent amblyopia and ensure proper visual development. Cataract surgery is the removal of the lens of the eye that has become opaque. In children, this is typically followed by the implantation of an intraocular lens.

 

Given the child is orthotropic (has normal eye alignment) and seems fine, the management would depend on the severity of the cataract and its effect on the child's vision. If the cataract is significant and affecting the child's vision, potentially leading to amblyopia, then cataract surgery would be the appropriate management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Convergence of Eye Muscle Exercises: are used to strengthen the eye muscles to improve binocular vision and treat convergence insufficiency. However, they are not a treatment for cataracts, which is a lens-related issue and not a muscle issue.

 

Option B. Reassurance: might be given if the cataract is very mild and not significantly affecting the child's vision. However, in children, even mild cataracts can lead to amblyopia (lazy eye) if not treated in a timely manner because visual development is ongoing.

 

Option D. Pilocarpine: is a medication used to constrict the pupil and reduce intraocular pressure, and it can also be used to manage acute angle-closure glaucoma. It is not a treatment for cataracts and would not be used as such in a child.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a 3-year-old child presenting with cataract, the management typically involves cataract surgery to prevent amblyopia and ensure normal visual development, unless the cataract is not significantly affecting vision.

questions.text: Plasma sterilization is used for the purpose of disinfection, to create the plasma which of the following substance is used? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hydrogen peroxide

 

Plasma sterilization is done with hydrogen peroxide. The mechanism of action is a free radical injury with hydrogen peroxide. Plasma sterilization is commonly used for sterilizing medical instruments that are sensitive to heat and moisture.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ethylene oxide: Incorrect. Ethylene oxide is used for sterilizing equipment like heart-lung machines, respirators, and dental instruments, but it is not used in plasma sterilization.

 

Option B. Glutaraldehyde: Incorrect. Glutaraldehyde is used for high-level disinfection of medical equipment like cystoscopes, bronchoscopes, and plastic endotracheal tubes but is not involved in plasma sterilization.

 

Option C. Formaldehyde: Incorrect. Formaldehyde is used for fumigation of operating theaters, wards, and laboratories but is not used in plasma sterilization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Plasma sterilization: Is done with hydrogen peroxide, which creates reactive species that effectively sterilize medical instruments through free radical injury.
  • Ethylene oxide - Heart lung machines, respirators, dental equipments etc.
  • Gluteraldehyde - Cystoscopes, bronchoscopes, Plastic ETT, face masks etc.
  • Formaldehyde - Fumigation of operating theater's, wards and labs.

questions.text: Contact based isolation is employed for which of the following diseases? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) MRSA

 

Contact-based isolation precautions are specifically employed for managing patients who are infected with or are carriers of MRSA (methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus). MRSA is known for its ability to spread via direct contact with infected or colonized individuals, or indirectly through contact with contaminated surfaces and objects. This isolation strategy involves using personal protective equipment, such as gloves and gowns, when interacting with the patient, and applying rigorous hygiene practices to prevent the spread of the bacterium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diphtheria: While also a communicable disease, it primarily requires droplet-based isolation due to its transmission through respiratory droplets.

 

Option C. Mumps: Similar to diphtheria, mumps is spread through respiratory droplets and thus requires droplet precautions.

 

Option D. Asthma: Not an infectious disease; it is a chronic respiratory condition that does not require transmission-based precautions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The three categories of transmission-based precautions include:

 

  • Contact- based isolation is used for infections, diseases, or germs that are spread by touching the patient or items in the room. Examples include MRSA, VRE, diarrheal illnesses, open wounds, and RSV.
  • Droplet-based isolation is employed for diphtheria and mumps.
  • Airborne precautions are required to protect against conditions like measles, severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), varicella (chickenpox), and Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

questions.text: A city school board is determining the minimum classroom space per student for safety and well-being. What is the minimum per capita space that should be available for each child in a school classroom based on public health guidelines? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. > 10 Sqft

 

The minimum per capita space required for each child in a school classroom is greater than 10 square feet, ensuring adequate space for safety and comfort.

 

Educational Objective:

 

School health service guidelines recommendations are:

 

  • One class room for maximum 40 students
  • Minus type desk
  • Doors and windows ≥ 25% of floor area
  • 1 urinal /60 student, 1 latrine/100 student.
  • Natural light from left side
  • Minimum area 10 sq. ft. per student for sitting.
  • School health examination every 6 months.
  • Walls should be white in colour.
  • Canteen should be present if number of students are more than 250.

choices.text: Add budesonide with monitoring of plasma levels of these drugs
Monitor plasma levels of ipratropium and formoterol

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient with bronchial asthma is currently on inhaler therapy with ipratropium and formoterol. Despite the medication, his symptoms are not improving due to hand-mouth incoordination. What should be the next step in management? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Use a spacer device

 

In patients with bronchial asthma, effective delivery of inhaled medications is crucial for symptom control. When a patient experiences hand-mouth incoordination, they may not be able to use their inhaler correctly, leading to poor drug delivery and inadequate symptom control. A spacer device helps overcome this issue by simplifying the inhalation process, ensuring better delivery of the medication to the lungs. The spacer holds the medication released from the inhaler, allowing the patient to inhale it slowly and more effectively, improving the coordination between actuation and inhalation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Add budesonide with monitoring of plasma levels of these drugs: Adding budesonide, an inhaled corticosteroid, might help in controlling asthma symptoms, but it does not address the fundamental problem of hand-mouth incoordination. Monitoring plasma levels is generally unnecessary for inhaled medications in this context.

 

Option B. Monitor plasma levels of ipratropium and formoterol: Monitoring plasma levels of inhaled medications is not a standard practice and does not address the issue of poor inhaler technique due to hand-mouth incoordination.

 

Option D. Switch to oral corticosteroids: While oral corticosteroids can be effective for severe asthma exacerbations, they have significant side effects and are not a preferred long-term solution for managing chronic asthma symptoms due to poor inhaler technique.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For asthma patients with hand-mouth incoordination, using a spacer device is an effective solution to improve medication delivery and symptom control.

choices.text: Intensity is inversely proportional to squared distance
Small blood vessels are most radioresistant
Rapidly proliferating cells are most radioresistant

questions.text: A woman with endometrial carcinoma is undergoing radiotherapy. Which of the following is true? (NEET PF 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Intensity is inversely proportional to squared distance

 

Explanation

 

This statement refers to the Inverse Square Law, which states that the intensity of radiation is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source. This means that as the distance from the radiation source increases, the intensity of the radiation decreases exponentially. This law is fundamental in radiation physics and is crucial for understanding radiation exposure and protection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Small blood vessels are most radioresistant: This is incorrect. Larger vessels are more radioresistant compared to smaller ones. The endothelial cells lining small vessels are more susceptible to radiation damage due to their relatively higher rate of proliferation.

 

Option C. Rapidly proliferating cells are most radioresistant: This is incorrect. Rapidly proliferating cells are the most radiosensitive. Cells that are dividing quickly, such as those in the gastrointestinal tract, bone marrow, and reproductive tissues, are more susceptible to radiation damage because radiation primarily affects DNA during cell division.

 

Option D. Small bowel is most radioresistant: This is incorrect. The gastrointestinal (GI) tract, including the small bowel, is among the most radiosensitive organ systems in the body. This high radiosensitivity is due to the rapid turnover of the epithelial cells lining the GI tract.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The intensity of radiation is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source, as described by the Inverse Square Law.

 

Ref: Page no 610, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

questions.text: Which of the following middle ear structure is a derivative of neural crest cells?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Foot plate of stapes

 

The malleus, incus, and stapes are the three ossicles of the middle ear that transmit sound vibrations from the eardrum to the inner ear. 

 

The footplate of the stapes is the portion of the stapes that sits in the oval window of the cochlea. It is unique among the ossicles because its development involves contributions from neural crest cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Malleus: Develops from the first branchial (pharyngeal) arch, also known as Meckel's cartilage, which is not derived from neural crest cells.

 

Option B. Stapes: While it is part of the same series of ossicles as the malleus, the main structure of the stapes develops from the second branchial (pharyngeal) arch, known as Reichert's cartilage, which is also not derived from neural crest cells.

 

Option D. Incus: Like the malleus, is derived from the first pharyngeal arch. It too is not a derivative of neural crest cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The footplate of the stapes in the middle ear is the structure derived from neural crest cells, distinguishing it from the other ossicles (malleus and incus), which are derived from the first and second pharyngeal arches and not from neural crest cells.

questions.text: A defect in which of the following forms the structure marked below as A? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Fascia transversalis

 

Marked structure is the deep inguinal ring, formed by a defect in fascia transversalis.

 

The deep inguinal ring is an opening in the transversalis fascia present 1 cm above the inguinal ligament, midway between the anterior superior iliac spine and the pubic symphysis.

 

An indirect inguinal hernia arises through the deep inguinal ring, lateral to the inferior epigastric vessel.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Internal Oblique:  The internal oblique muscle is one of the three major muscles of the lateral abdominal wall. It lies just deep to the external oblique and superficial to the transversus abdominis.

 

  • Origin and Insertion: It originates from the lumbar fascia, anterior two-thirds of the iliac crest, and lateral half of the inguinal ligament. It inserts into the lower ribs, linea alba, and the pubic bone.
  • Innervation: It is innervated by the lower six thoracoabdominal nerves and the first lumbar nerve.

 

Option B. External Oblique: The external oblique is the most superficial of the three flat muscles of the lateral abdominal wall.

 

  • Origin and Insertion: It originates from the outer surfaces of the 5th to 12th ribs and inserts into the linea alba, pubic tubercle, and anterior half of the iliac crest.
  • Innervation: Like the internal oblique, it's innervated by the lower six thoracoabdominal nerves and the first lumbar nerve.

 

Option C. Parietal Peritoneum: The parietal peritoneum is the outer layer of the peritoneum that lines the internal surface of the abdominal wall.

 

  • Composition: It consists of a single layer of squamous epithelial cells (mesothelium) and its underlying connective tissue.
  • Innervation: The parietal peritoneum overlying the anterior abdominal wall is primarily innervated by the lower six thoracoabdominal nerves and the first lumbar nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fascia Transversalis: The fascia transversalis is a thin aponeurotic membrane which lies between the inner surface of the transversus abdominis muscle and the parietal peritoneum. It covers the entire inner surface of the abdominal wall and is continuous with the iliac and pelvic fasciae.

 

Hernias that penetrate the fascia transversalis in the groin region are called direct inguinal hernias.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presented to the hospital with palpitations. Physical examination showed a diastolic murmur in the left 3rd intercostal space. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Aortic regurgitation

 

The presence of a diastolic murmur heard best at the left 3rd intercostal space (Erb's point) is characteristic of aortic regurgitation. Aortic regurgitation occurs when the aortic valve does not close properly, allowing blood to flow back into the left ventricle during diastole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aortic stenosis: This condition produces a systolic ejection murmur, typically heard at the right second intercostal space.

 

Option C. Mitral regurgitation: This condition causes a pansystolic murmur heard best at the apex of the heart and radiates to the axilla.

 

Option D. Tricuspid regurgitation: This condition causes a pansystolic murmur heard best at the lower left sternal border.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aortic Regurgitation is associated with a diastolic murmur, best heard at Erb’s point (left 3rd intercostal space). The murmur is typically described as a high-pitched, blowing, decrescendo murmur.

questions.text: Most common cause of thrombocytopenia in pregnancy? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gestational thrombocytopenia

 

Gestational thrombocytopenia is the most common cause of thrombocytopenia in pregnancy. It is generally a benign condition associated with mild thrombocytopenia, where platelet counts typically range between 100,000 to 150,000 per microliter. It is not linked to adverse pregnancy outcomes and usually resolves spontaneously after delivery. The exact cause is not well understood, but it is believed to be related to the normal hemodilution and increased platelet turnover during pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ITP (Idiopathic Thrombocytopenic Purpura): While ITP can cause thrombocytopenia in pregnancy, it is less common than gestational thrombocytopenia. ITP involves an autoimmune response leading to severe platelet destruction.

 

Option C. HELLP syndrome: HELLP syndrome is a severe form of preeclampsia that includes hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelets. While it causes thrombocytopenia, it is not as common as gestational thrombocytopenia.

 

Option D. Malaria in pregnancy: Malaria can cause thrombocytopenia, but it is not the most common cause during pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gestational thrombocytopenia is the most common cause of mild thrombocytopenia during pregnancy and is usually not associated with adverse outcomes.

questions.text: A farmer presented with history of ingestion of an unknown substance. He had increased sweating, lacrimation, diarrhea, muscle weakness, and tachycardia. What is the drug of choice for treatment? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Atropine

 

The above clinical scenario suggests organophosphate poisoning.

 

DOC for treatment- Atropine.

 

Though pralidoxime can also be given, but the main drug of choice is Atropine

 

 

SYMPTOMS:

 

 

MANAGEMENT:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Calcium gluconate: Calcium gluconate is used in cases of calcium deficiency or hyperkalemia.

 

Option C. Pralidoxime: Pralidoxime is a reactivator of acetylcholinesterase and is used in combination with atropine to treat organophosphate poisoning. However, it is not the primary drug of choice; atropine is.

 

Option D. Obidoxime: Obidoxime is also an acetylcholinesterase reactivator similar to pralidoxime, used in organophosphate poisoning, but not the primary drug of choice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of organophosphate poisoning presenting with symptoms like increased sweating, lacrimation, diarrhea, muscle weakness, and tachycardia, Atropine is the primary drug of choice for treatment. It acts by competitively inhibiting the muscarinic effects of acetylcholine.

questions.text: A patient presents with fatigue, pallor, and weakness. On evaluation, CBC reveals low hemoglobin with increased reticulocyte count. Comment on the likely diagnosis. (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hemolytic anemia

 

The clinical presentation of fatigue, pallor, and weakness, along with the laboratory findings of low hemoglobin and increased reticulocyte count, strongly suggests hemolytic anemia.

 

In hemolytic anemia, there is an increased destruction of red blood cells (RBCs), which leads to a compensatory increase in the production of RBCs by the bone marrow. This increased production is reflected by a higher reticulocyte count, which indicates that the bone marrow is responding to the anemia by releasing more immature red blood cells (reticulocytes) into the bloodstream.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aplastic anemia: Typically presents with pancytopenia (low counts of all blood cells) and a low reticulocyte count, reflecting bone marrow failure.

 

Option B. Anemia of chronic disease: Often shows a normal or low reticulocyte count because the bone marrow is not responding effectively due to chronic inflammation or disease.

 

Option C. Folate deficiency: Leads to megaloblastic anemia, where there is impaired DNA synthesis, resulting in large, immature RBCs with a normal or low reticulocyte count.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An increased reticulocyte count in the presence of low hemoglobin suggests an overactive bone marrow, often due to hemolytic anemia, where the body compensates for increased RBC destruction by ramping up RBC production.
